Award.AwardTitle: 4th AASHE Workshop on Research For Sustainability: Symposium on Research Opportunities in the Food, Energy, Water Systems Nexus (Baltimore, MD) - October 9, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1643237
Boss, Stephen K.

This grant is to help support participation of researchers and students in the 4th AASHE Workshop on Research for Sustainability: Colloquium on the Food, Energy, Water Systems Nexus. The workshop will be convened as a 1-day, pre-meeting workshop in association with the annual conference of the Association for the Advancement of Sustainability in Higher Education (AASHE) in Baltimore, MD on Sunday, 9 October 2016. The workshop will focus on presenting opportunities for research across the FEWS nexus from the National Science Foundation, Department of Energy, Environmental Protection Agency, and U.S. Department of Agriculture for academic researchers.

The emphasis of this workshop on issues at the nexus of food, energy, and water and opportunities for this research through programs of several federal agencies will aid in expanding the audience of prospective researchers competing in these programs. Assembling academic sustainability researchers at this workshop will facilitate synergy between the sustainability research community and federal agency programs providing resources for innovative and interdisciplinary solutions across the FEWS nexus.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The AASHE 4TH Annual Workshop on Research in Sustainability: Colloquium on Research Innovation in Food, Energy, Water Systems Nexus was an 8-hour (1-day) symposium convened at the annual conference of the Association for the Advancement of Sustainability in Higher Education (AASHE) in Baltimore, MD on 9 October 2016.

This colloquium focused on the interdependencies related to the production, extraction, generation and use of food, energy, and water and the impacts at the nexus of food, energy, water systems relative to sustainability. U.S. federal agencies (National Science Foundation, Department of Energy, Environmental Protection Agency, and Department of Agriculture) recognize these essential challenges which are compounded by climate change and population growth, and are taking steps to lead through agency initiatives (e.g. INFEWS) mobilizing the research community to engage in interdisciplinary research resulting from such interdependencies. 

The symposium featured 1-hour presentations from representatives of leading U.S. government agencies (National Science Foundation, Department of Energy, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, U.S. Department of Agriculture) with research priorities in the Food, Energy, Water Systems nexus (FEWS). The symposium also provided information for participants on opportunities to align collaboration between government agencies and academic institutions.

Featured speakers were:

Dr. Roderick Jackson, Group Leader, Building Envelopes System Research, Energy and Transportation Science Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy. Dr. Jackson’s presentation, “From ‘What If’ to ‘What’s Next’, began with an overview of ORNL mission areas and organizational structure. ORNL research efforts and opportunities addressing questions “What if we could make our power systems independent and resilient?” and “What if we could share energy for our vehicles and our buildings?” provided insights into progress with integrated energy systems for buildings and transportation. Future research questions were outlined and opportunities for academic participation in research were provided.

Ms. Lana Suarez, Director, Sustainable Food Management Program, Resource Conservation & Sustainability Division, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. Ms. Suarez’ presentation was entitled “Food Waste:  Challenges & Opportunities” documented annual food waste of 70 billion pounds, representing economic costs of $161 billion. She provided information U.S. EPA information, education, and outreach on food waste issues and methods to minimize food waste. She also presented a number of research opportunities related to food waste issues that would be of interest to U.S. EPA efforts in this domain.

Dr. Kim Green, Director, Office of the Chief Scientist, United States Department of Agriculture. Dr. Green presented “FEWS at USDA:  Current Research and Opportunities for Innovation” provided an overview of significant challenges facing world agriculture such as increasing efficiency of water use, reducing the environmental footprint of agriculture, biofuels and bioenergy synthesis, and producing safe and nutritious food. The presentation ended with a call for scientists and academic institutions to join USDA research efforts to provide for human needs through the end of the century.

Dr. Joann Slama-Lighty, Division Director, CBET, ENG, Co-Chair, INFEWS Working Group, National Science Foundation. Dr. Slama-Lighty presented symposium participants with an overview of NSF initiatives related to the FEWS nexus and information relevant to the process to apply for awards from NSF in this area. She advocated for  interdisciplinary approaches to FEWS issues and encouraged collaborations among multiple individuals and institutions with different expertise to solve future problems of the FEWS nexus for humanity.

Dr. Stephen K. Boss, Professor of Environmental Dynamics and Sustainability, Department of Geosciences, University of Arkansas. Prof. Boss made two presentations. The first, “Energy Output of Global Agriculture, 1961-2013”, documented the total energy derived from agricultural products and partitioning of that energy among food for humanity, feed for livestock, appropriation for biofuels synthesis, and waste. It concluded that societal decisions regarding this partitioning are more critical factors than increased agricultural production. The second presentation, “The Human Natural Resource Endowment: A New Measure of A Fundamental Human Right”, was new research documenting per capita natural resource consumption and suggested there exists a threshold significantly greater than depletion where natural resources are not sufficient to support human needs.

Dr. Tahar Messadi, 21st Century Professor of Sustainability, Fay Jones School of Architecture + Design, University of Arkansas. Prof. Messadi’s presentation, “Outlook for More Sustainable Buidling Stock”, was a synthesis of research efforts to improve the energy and water efficiency of all classes of buildings in the United States. It documented the gross energy consumption of building stock (40% of total energy) and the doubling of building stocks by year 2100. It advocated for partnerships of government, private sector, and universities/research facilities to improve building sustainability to meet needs of future populations.

The symposium participants ended the colloquium with a 1-hour discussion, question and answer period to review what had been learned and network with agency presenters regarding research opportunities.

Colloquium participants came away with a clear roadmap to advance research in the food, energy, and water systems nexus that are resilient to a hot and crowded future.
